title.narrative: Yes I do Pakistan

description.narrative: Activities include: development/adaptation information package on the specific Yes I Do objectives; organizing awareness sessions on social and gender norms, child rights and SRHR in the communities; strengthening of CSOs including Child Protection Committees on their institutional capacities and knowledge of child protection and SHRH laws and policie

Deep-rooted norms and expectations of girls and boys makes families and communities feel the need to control the sexuality of girls by marrying them off. Gender inequality is putting (married) girls in a subordinate position with regard to boys and men in (sexual) relationships. Girls and boys lack a voice, as well as the support to break through these norms and practices. The means and structures available for adolescents to organise themselves are limited and they have little access to adolescent-friendly and good quality SRH information and services. There are close links between EM and teenage pregnancies and girls’ lack of education and access to economic opportunities. Indeed, girls’ access to secondary and vocational education is very restricted, which makes it difficult for them to find jobs later. It also hampers their economic independence. Legislation to outlaw EM is either inadequate or is being poorly implemented.

Eearly Marriage and teenage pregnancies mutually reinforce one another. Social and gender norms perpetuating EM are deeply embedded in communities and this situation can only be changed if community leaders and most of the people, including boys and men, support the change. Key persons in the communities, including boys and men, will be turned into allies in the process of changing these norms, thereby helping to address the problem of EM and teenage pregnancies. A general lack of information about SRHR and poor quality and access to the relevant services are perpetuating the above-mentioned problems. Further, the social and gender norms denies especially to girls adequate access to quality secondary education and vocational training. Adolescent boys and girls are being informed about SRHR and given a voice to claim these rights. Girls are being given more control over their lives. This is being achieved by changing these norms and people’s behaviour, strengthening networks and structures for social mobilisation and embedding these in communities, and by involving the government and the private sector in improving SRHR and services. Improved access especially for girls to secondary education and vocational training will enhance their career opportunities and economic independence. All these will help to reduce EM and teenage pregnancies.
Final beneficiaries are girls between the age of 12 – 24 years, married and unmarried

SUMMARY Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM), teenage pregnancies (TP) and female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C). With the Yes I Do program, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM and teenage pregnancies. In Pakistan, the project was implemented by Plan Pakistan and Rutgers Pakistan with KIT as research partner. The project was implemented between January 2016 and December 2018 in selected areas in Umerkot and Sanghar districts in Sindh province. The project ended end 2018 because the offices of Plan and Rutgers in Pakistan had to close down by the Pakistan government and all activities to be ended.

Sustainability will be achieved a.o. through strengthening of local CSOs including youth led in their institutional and knowledge capacities, involvement of and cooperation with key stakeholders including local government representatives, community and religious leaders and private partners. Key research gaps will be identified with the key stakeholders and direct beneficiaries and will be addressed to improve evidence based lobby and advocacy towards preventing CM and TP. Further strategies to enhance sustainability will be developed in the course of the project implementation.

The programme is being implemented by the Yes I Do alliance in which each partner is adding value by implementing part of one or more of the intervention strategies. Paksitan was selected based upon on-going programmes of the alliance partners Plan and Rutgers onEM and teenage pregnancies.

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

policy-marker.narrative: DECIDE - Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR)
Protection against violence (including gender based violence)

provider-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: 0154 Children, youth or adults have skills to make changes to their lives
% girls aged 15-18 currently attending secondary school (Sanghar)

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Sanghar and Umerkot). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1600 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1602 questionnaires were administered.

comment.narrative: % girls aged 15-18 currently attending secondary school (Sanghar)

title.narrative: 0551 Service providers are capable to deliver services that are sensitive to rights of children and youth and gender equality (C2)
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is a problem

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is a problem

title.narrative: Children, youth or adults decide about their own future
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in perceived autonomy of girls between 15 – 24 years old

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in perceived autonomy of girls between 15 – 24 years old

Some level of (perceived) autonomy is observed in girls between 15-24 years old, especially if they have been engaged in the Yes I Do programme as Kirans or Kirans+. However young people mentioned wanting to have more decision-making power.

title.narrative: 0000 Performance Plan Nederland as a development organisation
0000.6 Gender score of the program design and activities (0=Not measured; 1=Gender Blind; 2=Gender Neutral; 3=Gender Aware; 4=Gender Transformative)

comment.narrative: 0000.6 Gender score of the program design and activities (0=Not measured; 1=Gender Blind; 2=Gender Neutral; 3=Gender Aware; 4=Gender Transformative)
Good attention for gender inequality/fully gender aware however not transformative
Progress on realizing of gender transformative approach a.o. in youth groups set up and methodolgy however in the social context gender transformative approach is difficult to realize

title.narrative: 1400 Dissemination of rights information to children, youth or adults
Number of children, youth or adults informed about the rights of children and youth

comment.narrative: Number of children, youth or adults informed about the rights of children and youth

Girls are formed in groups and informed about their education and economic empowerment rights, are formed in groups and as such will interact with their community members to help improve social support and facilities for access to education, vocational training and set up small home businesses.
111 girls were organized in 15 groups and informed about their educational and economic empowerment rights and capacitated to interact as groups with their community members

title.narrative: Number of children, youth or adults informed about the rights of children and youth

comment.narrative: Number of children, youth or adults informed about the rights of children and youth
82 boys formed in groups to be informed on rights of girls and boys on education and economic empowerment.

89 boys were formed in 15 groups and informed on the education and economic empowerment rights of girls and boys; as groups they interact with their communities to help improve facilities and support for the rights of girls and boys.

title.narrative: 1000 Vocational, business and life skills training for children, youth or adults

comment.narrative: Total girls and boys who receive career counselling information during sessions
464 (281 girls,183 boys) in School. 777 (449 Girls,328 Boys) in communities participated in career counselling sessions through the method Exploring Career Choices
# of youth (girls and boys) reached with career counselling sessions

title.narrative: Number of children, youth or adults who participated in vocational, business, or life skills training

comment.narrative: Selected girls who dropped out of school and are too old to return to the formal secondary school will be provided with basic vocational skills training in a market-relevant trade
54 girls aged 18-19 received vocational skills training of on average 45 days in various skills including basic computer skills, beautician, tailoring)
70 girls and young women under 20 received a three month handi skills training in embroidery,tailoring, beautician and computer skills
Girls who receive and guidance to start a home-based business
Previously trained girls (vocational training on handy skills including embroidery, beautician) received toolkits and guidance to start a business from their home

title.narrative: Number of children, youth or adults who participated in vocational, business, or life skills training

comment.narrative: Boys who received solar panel maintenance training

title.narrative: 3100 Rights training for CSOs
Number of CSOs reached with rights training

comment.narrative: Sepearate groups of boys and girls capacitated on dialoguing with their communities on CM and its consequences, and to prevent CM in their villages and amongst their peers

CSO members and staff received at least one day capacity building on Sindh province CM law, policies and issues that prevent the implementing thereof as well as rights of children/ youth to have access to quality ASRHR information and services

title.narrative: 5300 Operational support for service providers, including funding
Number of service providers reached with operational support

comment.narrative: 3 TVET institutions in Hyderabad (where YIDA in 2018 started as new working area) which were not functional (closed) were renovated with basic necessities i-e furniture including cutting tables and chairs, computer shelves and fitted tables, Desktop computers, White boards, Floor mats, UPS and Battery, Pico Machines and Advance tailoring machines etc under the supervision of Social welfare department

title.narrative: Dialoguing with government
Number of government officials sesitized

comment.narrative: 34 men and 7 women officials reached in 2 dialogue sessions

title.narrative: 0112 Children, youth or adults influence decision making in families and communities
Number of children and youth who are involved in influencing others in their families and communities

comment.narrative: 75 boys organized in Youth Forums in Umerkot (will be phased out), 125 in Youth Forums in Sanghar of which 89 in newly formed groups in 2018
200 adolescent boys in total are organized and supported in Youth Forums which are active in their communities

title.narrative: Number of children and youth who are involved in influencing others in their families and communities

comment.narrative: # of girls organized in Youth Forums. Locations in Umerkot will be phased out by mid-2018, # of locations in Sanghar will be expanded

Youth Forum groups of girls were set up in 2017 and are functional till mid-2018 in Umerkot, however YIDA will phase-out from Umerkot. Youth forum groups of girls are supported in Sanghar of which 111 girls are part of newly set up groups in 2018. These groups are active in their communities to inform the community members on harmful effects of CM and SGBV.
